text.headline: Black Hawk in the midwest, 1767-1812
text.text:
A warrior of the Thakiwaki (Sauk) tribe, Black Hawk (1767-1838) grew up in a village on the Rock River, near the site of present-day Rock Island, Illinois. He led his people in the War of 1812, fighting alongside the British, and during the 1832 Black Hawk War, against the United States. Following his capture and imprisonment in 1832, Black Hawk told his life story to an interpreter and a newspaper editor, and published the first Native American autobiography in the U.S. Life of Ma-Ka-Tai-Me-She-Kia-Kiak or Black Hawk, became an instant bestseller and a classic text for those studying settler-colonial violence in the United States.

Book excerpts from: Life of Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak or Black Hawk, 1833. Newberry Library View at Internet Archive | Map: Ornamental map of the United States & Mexico, 1846. Newberry Library View at Internet Archive

text.headline: Sac Village, 1767
text.text:
"I was born at the Sac Village, on Rock River, in the year 1767...

"Few, if any, events of note, transpired within my recollection, till about my fifteenth year. I was not allowed to paint, or wear feathers; but distinguished myself, at that early age, by wounding an enemy; consequently, I was placed in the ranks of the Braves!"

--Life of Black Hawk, or Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak View digitized item

text.headline: Merimack, 1786
text.text:
"Our attention was directed towards an ancient enemy, who had decoyed and murdered some of our helpless women and children. I started, with my father, who took command of a small party, and proceeded against the enemy. We met near Merimack, and an action ensued, the Cherokees having greatly the advantage in numbers.

"Early in this engagement my father was wounded in the thigh... Nothing could be done for him. The medicine man said the wound was mortal! from which he soon after died! ... I now fell heir to the great medicine bag of my forefathers, which had belonged to my father."

--Life of Black Hawk, or Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak View digitized item

text.headline: Prairie du chien, 1812
text.text:
"News reached us that a war was going to take place between the British and the Americans. The British agent, Col. Dixon, was holding talks with, and making presents to, the different tribes. I had not made up my mind whether to join the British, or remain neutral. I had not discovered one good trait in the character of the Americans that had come to the country! They made fair promises, but never fulfilled them! Whilst the British made but few -- but we could always rely upon their word!

"...Why did the Great Spirit ever send the whites to this island, to drive us from our homes, and introduce among us poisonous liquors, disease, and death?"

--Life of Black Hawk, or Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak View digitized item

text.headline: Chicago, 1812
text.text:
"We passed Chicago. The fort had been evacuated by the American soldiers, who had marched for fort Wayne. They were attacked a short distance from that fort, and defeated! They had a considerable quantity of powder in the fort at Chicago, which they had promised to the Indians; but the night before they marched, they destroyed it. I think it was thrown into the well! If they had fulfilled their word to the Indians, I think they would have gone safe."

--Life of Black Hawk, or Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak View digitized item

text.headline: Sac Village, 1812
text.text:
"I then started to visit my wife and children. I found them well, and my boys were growing finely. It is not customary for us to say much about our women, as they generally perform their part cheerfully, and never interfere with business belonging to the men! This is the only wife I ever had, or ever will have. She is a good woman, and teaches my boys to be brave! Here I would have rested myself, and enjoyed the comforts of my lodge, but I could not: I had promised to avenge the death of my adopted son!"

--Life of Black Hawk, or Ma-ka-tai-me-she-kia-kiak View digitized item
